content.webTitle: Matildas rally as thread of negativity fails to unravel Women's World Cup hopes | Richard Parkin

fields.headline: Matildas rally as thread of negativity fails to unravel Women's World Cup hopes
fields.bodyText: “That was unbelievable. I think that’s one of the most exciting games I’ve ever played in. It was a game that’s had absolutely everything – from controversial decisions, VAR decisions, to a comeback victory – I mean what else can you ask for?” As Elise Kellond-Knight succinctly captured, more than any game so far at the France 2019 World Cup, Australia’s remarkable 3-2 win over Brazil deserved to be acclaimed as a celebration of football. Two nations bound in mutual distemper, packed with champion players, either at their peak or in the twilight of their powers, scrapping and fighting with an intensity and determination that was palpable from the stands. Whereas some teams play with physicality and others with skill, both the Matildas and Canarinhas were exemplars of both. Tamires’ nutmeg on Emily Gielnik, Cristiane’s cool juggle, Sam Kerr’s remarkable improvised first-time finish that almost caught out Barbara. And yet somehow, amid all the reaction to this pulsating game, a stubbornly resistant thread of negativity has crept in once again. Kerr’s buoyant post-match expression of personality was branded “immature”, some even questioned whether the “haters” she was responding to even existed. Commentators from back home concluded that Kerr must be mistaken – because all of Australia was behind the Matildas. An entirely acceptable claim if you’re oblivious to the homophobic or sexist abuse hurled daily at female players – something that’s exacerbated by an environment in which a months-old controversy is given greater prominence throughout the first week of the tournament than the voices or the actions of the Matildas themselves. There are no shortage of remarkable stories from within this tight-knit group of players. Hayley Raso’s recovery from a broken back, Lisa De Vanna’s quest to score at a fourth consecutive World Cup, even player of the match Chloe Logarzo’s star turn in Montpellier, just a few years after nearly walking away from the game. Kellond-Knight, a player coming into France 2019 under an injury cloud, not only made a positive return against Brazil, but completed 90 minutes for the first time in three months, solving Australia’s left-back conundrum at the same time. Logarzo and Tameka Yallop got through a power of work in midfield, but more than that, their positive aggression helped tip the scales Australia’s way as the match progressed. To come away clutching at a cloud from one of Australia’s biggest silver lining evenings takes almost a wilful ignorance of the sheer joyousness fans witnessed in Montpellier. With so much pressure, and potentially the Matildas’ World Cup hopes on the line, the win over Brazil finally shuts down some persistently nagging questions – firstly, whether the players have bought into Milicic’s footballing vision, and secondly, whether it can be a successful one. “People don’t understand the belief we have in this team,” said Kerr. “They don’t understand the confidence we have in each other, the confidence we have in Ante.” Accidentally leaving her player of the match trophy at the press conference, Logarzo quipped that she’d left it behind deliberately for “coach” – “the real player of the match”. “I think that win was definitely for Ante,” Logarzo said earlier in the night. “The criticism is more on his behalf, and it’s really disheartening for us to hear that because the amount of belief he’s instilled in us and the amount of work he’s put in is incredible.” The players have told us time and time again – before and during the tournament, offering glowing endorsements of Milicic’s attention to detail, sophisticated tactical planning, and ability to pick up the playing group again after the tumultuous events of January. The result against Brazil was impressive, but it was the manner in which it was achieved – only the second time in World Cup history a team has successfully turned around a two-goal deficit – that deserves celebrating. A fervent adherent to process, Milicic often declines extensive comment on a performance until he’s “run the tape”. After the Italy game, the Matildas supremo’s assessment remained upbeat. “We dominated possession. We dominated shots on goal and we dominated territory. We created enough chances to win the game but unfortunately we’ve made an error in build up … I really feel like we deserved something from the game, but that’s the World Cup. We got nothing.” In game one, Italy were arguably denied a legitimate goal, Australia were caught napping the 95th minute. Against Brazil, Australia were arguably denied a legitimate penalty early on, but then rewarded with a winning goal that some considered contentious. “That’s football, isn’t it?” reflected a glowing Kellond-Knight in Montpellier. “You have to take it, you have to put the ball in there, you have to make luck in a way. Sometimes people say goals are just luck but you’re making the luck – you’re dominating the game, you’re making the play, so in a way we created those chances, with a bit of fortune.” The Matildas haven’t transformed from a low-confidence team under an untested coach to tournament contenders again in just five days. And disproportionate criticism in defeat is not evened out by unbridled adulation after victory. As the Brazilian adage goes, people have two ears and one mouth, and should use them in that proportion. Listening to the players themselves rather than foisting preferred narratives upon them might just be a decent starting point. After all, there could yet be plenty more twists and turns left in store at France 2019.
